title: 109_hr5200
content: The Act titled "National Defense Enhancement and National Guard Empowerment Act of 2006" expands the authority of the Chief of the National Guard Bureau and the functions of the National Guard Bureau. The Act expands the authority of the Chief of the National Guard Bureau and enhances their advisory function on national guard matters. The Chief of the National Guard Bureau's authority is expanded to include duties as a member of the Joint Chiefs of Staff under section 151 of title 10, United States Code. The Act enhances their advisory role on national guard matters. The Chief of the National Guard Bureau's authority is expanded to include duties as a member of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. An annual report to Congress on validated requirements is required, detailing requirements validated in the previous fiscal year and funding requests for the next fiscal year. An annual report to Congress on validated requirements is required, detailing requirements validated in the previous fiscal year and funding requests for the next fiscal year. The Secretary of Defense, in consultation with the Secretary of the Army and the Secretary of the Air Force, shall develop the charter for the National Guard Bureau. The National Guard Bureau's expanded authority includes facilitating and coordinating with other federal agencies and states for contingency operations, military assistance for civil authorities, and other circumstances. The Chief of the National Guard Bureau is responsible for identifying gaps in Federal and State capabilities for emergency response and making recommendations to the Secretary of Defense for military assistance to civil authorities. This includes validating State requirements and developing training requirements in coordination with Adjutant Generals. The Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff assists in carrying out activities related to this responsibility. The Chief of the National Guard Bureau, in consultation with the Secretaries of the Army and Air Force, is responsible for budgeting for training and equipment for military assistance to civil authorities and other domestic missions. The budget justification documents submitted to Congress must specify separate amounts for these purposes. The funding specified should cover doctrine development, training requirements, equipment acquisition, and limit personnel increases within the National Guard Bureau. The National Guard Bureau, in consultation with the Army and Air Force Secretaries, must budget separately for training and equipment for domestic operations. Funding should cover doctrine development, training, equipment acquisition, and avoid personnel increases. Conforming and clerical amendments are made to section 10503 of the title. The National Guard Bureau must budget separately for training and equipment for domestic operations, including military assistance to civil authorities. Amendments are made to section 10503 of the title, and the position of Assistant to the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff for Reserve Matters is terminated. The position of Assistant to the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff for Reserve Matters is within the Joint Staff and is selected by the Chairman from officers of the Army Reserve, Navy Reserve, Marine Corps Reserve, or Air Force Reserve with at least 10 years of commissioned service in their reserve component and in a grade above colonel or captain. The term of office is two years, renewable for one additional term. The Assistant to the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff for Reserve Matters holds the grade of major general or rear admiral, serves as an advisor on reserve matters, and is selected from officers with at least 10 years of commissioned service in a grade above colonel or captain. There is no limit on the number of terms during wartime. The Secretary of Defense, in consultation with the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, develops policy guidance for other reserve component representation on the Joint Staff. The policy guidance ensures reserve component officer representation on the Joint Staff aligns with their significant role in the Total Force. SEC. 3. Promotion of eligible reserve officers to higher ranks on active-duty list. Sense of Congress is that reserve officers eligible for promotion to lieutenant general or vice admiral should be considered for promotion. The Secretary of Defense must propose mechanisms to achieve this objective, including legislative or administrative actions. The President must certify with each nomination of an officer for promotion to these grades on the active-duty list. The Senate receives a certification that all eligible reserve officers were considered for promotion in nominations. The position of Deputy Commander of the United States Northern Command must be filled by a National Guard officer eligible for promotion to lieutenant general to integrate National Guard Bureau information into the Command's plans and operations.
